narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith Martin

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was absolutely amazing! Seriously. She is extremely approachable, friendly, intelligent and available. One of the best TFs I've ever had.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  She was great, very professional. Going to be a wonderful professor in the future.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Helpful content expertise, relationship with Professor.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Meredith was knowledgeable and helpful. She was good at keeping Professor Peters on track, and the two complemented each other well.
Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  Very helpful in leading review sessions

Instructor: Meredith Pearl Martin  She knows the content of the course very well and she is familiarized with Chuck's teaching style. Her review sessions before the exams were very helpful. Her comments in class were relevant and illuminating.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 11. Professor Peters is incredibly enthusiastic about indigenous silviculture, with which he has had many personal experiences. This enthusiasm and experience combined to generate fifteen minutes-long soliloquies and anecdotes about various aspects of indigenous silviculture. While this sort of improvisation could definitely made the teaching more immersive and helped center the material in the real world, it could impede our progress into new topics. The course could have been a bit more focused. 12. Professor Peters could get tunnel vision sometimes. There were a few instances where this manifested itself as insensitive or tone-deaf responses to legitimate student comments about the social implications of various silvicultural systems. A memorable instance was his failure to directly address the oppression of the Putumayo people under the Peruvian rubber barons, following a student's attempt to make him do so. Overall, I really appreciated Prof. Peters' relaxed teaching style and profound enthusiasm for the subject.
My favorite course at FES

Chuck's knowledge and experience was paramount to understand how theory and practice feed each other. I personally learned a lot from Chucks stories of his research projects, each of his learnings and insights were illustrated by a real life story.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Chuck is an amazing professor, who really provided serious depth of knowledge in a topic that he is passionate about. Thank you so much for this course!

Professor has incredible knowledge and experience. Subject material is incredibly relevant. Classroom discussion was useful, student input and interaction strongly encouraged. Professor had clear lectures, and his presentation style and pedagogy were so refreshing!
It gave me a new perspective on tropical livelihoods and their interaction with western conservation and ecology.
Critical evaluation and curiosity

Overall, the course was one of my favorites at FES. It goes beyond the technical realm and explores the philosophical and social sciences realm as well, which in my opinion gives the student a more holistic and complete picture of the world's tropical forests and forestry sector. This is one of the few classes I took at FES which recognizes that everything is interconnected, and that is really interdisciplinary. This class allowed me to further develop the skill of studying something in detail without losing perspective of the whole, and

The instructor has a lot of experience with indigenous silviculture systems around the world which he shares in a very story-telling fashion that is very enriching. It is a course that promotes critical thinking about environmental programs that are applied still today and it also introduces to a way of thinking the forest as an integral part of agriculture and economy.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Hm.... I really don't have any feedback on this. Maybe some inclusion of temperate climates? Although I know that's not your speciality.
Nothing. This class is incredible and should be required for the entire FES student body.
It could be more focused.

It was very distracting to have other fellow students working on their computers in other things unrelated to the class. Perhaps the course would benefit from prohibiting students to use their laptops.

Despite being a course that critizices "western silvicuture" and stresses the importance of indigenous silvicuture, all the materials were from non indigenous authors. It would be great to take advantage of shared interests to get to hear about students experiences in the classroom. Instructor was not very receptive to discussion.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: In class discussions were the most nurturing part because that's when we would distill/digest first impressions and thoughts about the readings and lectures.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm all about the human dimensions of forestry.

The course was far from my specialty or interest. I was partly interested in the relationship and economics between commodities and communities - and learned quite a bit. Have to say overall I was impressed with what I managed to take away. His personal experience and on-the-ground context was priceless. Chuck Peters is a legend, he could have taught Indigenous Cooking Methods and it would have made an impact on my learning. His insight, experience, and intellect is invaluable. I hope he comes back to serve future students.
Wanted to learn more about agroforestry practices
Refer to question 17

comments: Personal interest.
Fascinated by the content.
Because I was interested in learning more about agroforestry and other traditional practices of managing tropical forests
I am interested in community-based forestry, land defense, landscape managing, forest policies

comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do not miss this class... though I don't know if it's being offered again by Chuck. If it is, TAKE IT! If another professor is teaching it, who knows.... but the content is incredibly fascinating.
Lecture can be frustrating, especially if you're a fan of order, but the material is interesting and worth knowing about.
Do the readings before class.
